page.title: 11LANDSCAPE AND NATURE
page.content: Denholme block ranges from{l,4OO {feet}a.s.l.to{75O feet }a.s.l. Generally hilly, with deep {cloughs} (or valleys) down from the rough moorland. The rock is {millstone grit used for dry stone walls, with evidence of boulder clay and coal measures. The soft water here attracted the woollen industry. The {prevailing winds} W.and S W. give a bracing, sometimes severe climate. The sun DOES shine, even when the valleys are shrouded in mist, and in contrast, the village is occasionally cut off by snow. Bilberries, heather, cotton grass grow on the moor, inhabited by rabbits, foxes and curlews. Yet by the more sheltered Doe Park reservoir wood anemores, milkmaids can be found, and swifts,swallows and owls make their homes here.
